Name: Screamin' Genie: The Frantic Sound & Race Game
Description:
From the box:

"Somewhere far away, in a deep, dark cave, lies a magic lamp full of precious stones. The lamp is guarded by a sleeping but fearsome genie.

Now you are about to discover this magic lamp. Your goal is to capture the precious stones, but to do it, you must first rub the lamp. Do you dare risk disturbing the genie to get them?

If the genie wakes up, you will be forced into a frantic race against time to save your stones and stop the genie as he screams! Can you win the race before the screaming stops?"

Name: Hierarchy
Description: This is a game where you try to get a suitable place in heaven via roll and move.  The pieces are wooden angel meeples and there are tokens you collect to put you in a particular choir placement.

Name: Back Alley
Description:
"Experience this exciting card game with the entire family!"

This is an "Oh Hell!" knockoff with just a few minor changes.  The deck is a standard 52, nicely done in four bold, primary colored suits and clear numbering 1 through 13.  There are also four "Back Alley" cards that serve as ubertrump wild cards. Prior to bidding, each player may exchange one of the cards in their hand for one of the cards not dealt, drawn blindly in turn order.  The scoring is also changed.  If the bid is met, you score three points for tricks bid and taken, plus one point for tricks greater than the bid.  If the bid isn't met, it's minus one point for each trick missed.

The game comes with clear rules that also give instructions for additional players.  A nice score pad in also included.

Name: Geysers of Yellowstone
Description:
Players are photographers trying to take the best pictures of geysers, hot springs, wildlife, hot springs, and scenery in Yellowstone National Park. Timing of geyser eruptions is card-driven. The board represents a portion of Yellowstone, and the game uses a point-to-point movement system.

The publisher's description:

There's nothing like the frenzied life of a photographer on a short deadline. You and your fellow shutterbugs have been sent to Yellowstone National Park with only one day to get all the pictures for a twelve-month calendar. At the end of the day, your publisher will pick the twelve best photos for the calendar. Your goal: get more pictures in the calendar than anyone else.

It won’t be easy. Should you gamble on the uncertain schedule of erupting geysers? Or stake out watering holes in hopes of getting a great shot of the wildlife? Grab your camera and get out on the road; you have until sundown to collect as many snapshots as you can. And don’t forget to take off your lens cap.

Geysers of Yellowstone is a quick-playing board game about the thrilling world of nature photography. Players move on a board that represents Yellowstone National Park, taking pictures of geysers, hot springs, wildlife, and scenery. Timing of geyser eruptions is card-driven. The player with the best photo portfolio at the end of the game is the winner.

Name: Mamma
Description: A family dinner is arranged and you are one of the members: however, this family has trust issues, and no one's certain who will spoil the pot! Dinner is served in this game of bluffing, cruelty and fun.

Name: Bible Baseball
Description:
Baseball is great family fun. Even young children can get a base hit or bring the whole team home with a dinger. Bible Baseball has been a home run in the classroom for years. Whether you use it as a “seventh inning stretch” between lesson series or as a “sandlot” game in a classroom learning center, Bible Baseball is a Christian education MVP. What a great combination: the big league thrill of baseball and the Word of God. Cheer your friends and family on as the knock one out of the park. You’ll have a great time and will also learn about the Bible.

The pitcher has hundreds of questions about God’s Word and the right answer can get the players on first, second, or third base. They can even get a home run! The colorful newly designed game board and pieces help keep track of who is on which base as well as the score and the number of outs. All that’s missing are the hot dogs and peanuts! Bible Baseball is great for family fun, but it also is helpful in the classroom or Sunday School setting.

Name: Maneuvering
Description:
From front cover:

"A Beautiful Game of Skill, Strategy, and Maneuvers"

From back cover:

Maneuvering is the new easy to learn game.  It is an action packed board game which combines skill, chance, and special maneuvers to determine a winner.  It incorporates an entirely new concept which is sophisticated and considerably more attractive than conventional board games. (i.e., chess or backgammon).  The game is played on a 15 1/2" x 15 1/2" Maneuvering board where each player has twenty-four ships to protect and defend.  To start the game, these ships are positioned in the first three rows of the board (as shown).  For each turn, the player rolls two dice.  He then moves 2 ships, one for each die the number of spaces indicated by both dice.  The object of the game is to capture all of your opponent's ships or to win by trapping your opponent's ship(s).  The first player to complete one of the game objectives is the winner!

Name: Hearts & Spades
Description: Hearts & Spades consists of 164 cards in two suits: Hearts and Spades. Score the least points by being the first player or team to exhaust your stockpile by playing on community piles.

Name: Terran
Description:
Terran was produced in Perth, Western Australia.  
It is basically an 8 x 8 chess style board with pieces moving around on the vertices's instead of in the squares.  There is an interesting center vertex which allows the bishop type pieces to change from one set of diagonals to the other.  There are five different types of pieces all with differing moves of 1 or 2 spaces (like restricted chess pieces).  The pieces are bright yellow and red plastic.  The aim of the game is to capture the opposition command center piece.

Name: Swords and Dice
Description:
Well researched, light Ancients rules covering the Greek and Persian Wars, the campaign of Alexander the Great, and the Second Punic War.

Written for individually based miniatures in movement trays. 
Each unit is rated for shooting, melee, morale and special abilities, and move and fight in strict formation. Fighting involves rolling lots of dice.

The rule set includes army lists and historical scenarios.

Name: Alva
Description:
An early game from the designer of Hey, That's My Fish!

The game is played on the intersections of a 9×9 grid, each player receives 34 pieces in their color.

A player's turn consists of either
1) Moving 1 piece to a neighboring empty point (optional), followed by placing a new piece on any empty point. (required)

or

2) Taking pieces by jumping over horizontal or vertical lines of their opponent's pieces. If this is possible, this must be done instead of moving/placing pieces via option 1.

Lines with 2 pieces cannot be jumped over, but any other amount can be. The jumping piece must continue jumping until no more jumps are possible. After each jump, the opponent's pieces are captured and removed from the board. If you capture the same number of pieces that your opponent just captured from you on the preceding turn, the pieces are returned to the opponent and not placed in your captured pile.

The game ends when a player cannot make any legal move. Each player gets one point for each captured opponent's piece, plus one point for each opponent's piece on the outside border of the board. Most points wins.

Name: Let's Go Hike
Description: Let's Go Hike is a simple 'spin & move' game set in the Boundary Waters Canoe Area.  Players select from an assortment of forest creature markers such as 'Shirley Squirrel' or 'Matthew Mallard', and race from the Gunflint Trail Ranger Station to the goal: Moon Lake campsite.

Name: Galaxy
Description:
The board depicts stars connected to each other by lines.  Each player takes turn placing a marker on a star, scoring one point for each connected star containing an opposing-player marker.  The game ends when the board is filled.  The player with the most points win.

Galaxy was created for Chief Herman's Holiday Fun Pack.

Name: Mr. Muscle
Description:
An interesting game that verges on being just a toy.  There is a plastic muscle-man, with an empty barbell, and yellow plastic discs as weights.  The game employs a winch system and a turn-crank, by which the players move the Mr. Muscle figure's arms to lift the barbell.

Theme: Weightlifting.  Children's game.

Name: The Napoleonic Wars
Description:
The Napoleonic Wars covers the entire period of conflict from 1796 to 1815.  Each turn represents 4 months.  The map is divided into areas, with terrain in the area (forest, swamp, etc.) and along the area borders (river, mountains, etc.). According to the rules, the pieces represent small corps or oversized divisions.  Some units also represent commanders that can command other units.  Fortresses are also represented by pieces.

The sequence of play is fairly standard for a wargame - 
1) Negotiations 
2) Rebuilding Cadres
3) Supply Determination
4) Movement and Combat
5) Reinforcements 
6) Adjustment of Revenue 
7) Move game turn marker

When playing one of the campaigns (i.e., not the full Napoleonic Wars), skip Negotiations, Rebuilding, and Revenue.

The Movement phase has a unique mechanic that requires units with lower (worse) leadership to move before those with better leadership, regardless of which country controls the unit.  Units which don't move when it is their turn may only move later if led by a commander with higher leadership.  A player may use his highest rated leader to preempt the movement of another player's lower rated leader.

This game was sold as a stand alone game with a paper map.  The game could also be played by combining the pieces and mounted maps from the other three games in the series (Napoleon's Italian Campaigns, Napoleon's Russian Campaign, and Napoleon's Peninsula Campaign) and adding the extra rules and pieces from Expansion Module 2.

Name: Music Maestro
Description: This is a game that lets a person learn about the musical instruments of the West.  It has five different games for various age ranges, ranging from 4 years to adult.

Name: Murder à la carte: A Cajun Killing
Description:
On the box:

The mystery - The scene is a riverboat plying the Mississippi.  Among the passengers is Benton Thorne, a plantation owner infamous for his ruthlessness.  The vacation his wife Rosie persuaded him to take is brought to an abrupt end by a murderer's blade.  With so many enemies, that's no surprise...or is it?

Name: Sylabex
Description:
Sylabex is a word-making game, easy to play in which both skill and luck are involved.

The cards all bear a three-letter syllable and a number (which is the points value used in scoring). Any cards when placed beside certain of the other cards forms a complete six letter word, or in some cases will form a nine letter word.

The object of the game is to make words with all the cards in your hand. Other players score the points value of the cards in hand when the round ends, and the winner is the player with the lowest score after the agreed numbers of rounds.

Name: PBI II: 15mm Scale Company Actions of World War 2
Description:
From publisher:
PBI is a game of company level combat in WW2. PBI is an infantry game with armor present as support. Artillery and the like is off table.

A set of WW2 company level rules. The game is played on a 4 foot by 4 foot grid, split into 6" squares. A company would typically consist of 3 tanks and 25 bases of infantry.

The scale is 1 to 1. This means that a base of three figures represents three men. A tank model represents a real tank. The tabletop scale is 10m to the inch.

The Overall concept.

PBI is intended to provide a two hour wargame. All of the dice used are simple D6. All of the mechanisms are intuitive. PBI uses a gridded board. This means that all movement, range and areas are described in terms of squares. Because the player takes the role of the company commander, the squares of the grid allow him to get soldiers to "go over there and do that", rather than measuring distances and engaging in single figure management. By using a grid it is very clear what scenery type the figures are in. There are three types of square. Closed (buildings and woods), Partial (hedges, walls and fences) and open (no significant cover).

The rules generate a scenario which both players have a fair chance of winning. The game is always of the attack/defense style.

PBI uses a lot of D6 (a typical section shooting would roll 10 dice). This helps give a feel for the massive amount of ammunition expended and allows the probabilities to even out (the more dice you roll, the more predictable the result).

The aim of PBI is to create company level engagements which players can win by use of better tactics. The game is focussed on the player being a company commander so those are the tasks given to the player.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players
Series: Poor Bloody Infantry – WWII Miniature Rules (Peter Pig)
Series: Rule For The Common Man (Peter Pig)

Name: Getaway
Description: An exciting game of Travel & Trivia using a factual world map as your playing board.  Players start with airline itineraries & travelers checks and need to be the first player to visit all the cities on their itinerary, collecting the appropriate visa, and return to their country of origin all the while managing their money, navigating detours & diversions.  The first player to collect 10 visas and return to their country of origin is declared the winner.  PLAY:  Players must announce their intended destination before the role of the die which will determine the amount of the fare.   The die role will determine the destination and the cost by displaying full/half or free fares.  If a player rolls divert, transit, geography or general knowledge then they must take the appropriate card from the board and their travel is suspended or diverted depending on the instructions of the card.  Many times players may answer trivia questions about their particular region to allow their flight to continue to their previously stated destination, however, a wrong answer usually keeps the player grounded or relocates them to an undesirable location.   Money is collected by opting not to fly and answering trivia questions or a combination of both.  The Australian game designer recommends this game for ages 12+.

Name: thwart
Description: Players start with 5 numbered tokens of their color. They must get rid of these, and acquire 5 new ones not of their color. Every spot on the board has a token/number associated with it. The board is a hexagon linked with 6 paths through the center. The players move counter-clockwise or through the center.

Name: Frontline General
Description:
The Frontline General 'Land, Air, & Sea Tabletop Simulation' is an Operational and Tactical Level WWII Consim.  The system covers Land, Air, and Sea wargaming mostly at the Operational level with a tactical 'feel'.  The board wargame may be used to 'drive' more detailed tabletop miniatures battles for decisive engagements.  Miniatures combat expands on the level of detail and is entirely optional.

Frontline General: Italian Campaign expands on the published introductory game, Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction, by adding a large size map of Southern Italy (See the Image Gallery), more Units, an additional country (the United Kingdom), and five historical scenarios covering action from Salerno to the Gustav Line.

The game will be available as a standalone game or as an upgrade to the Frontline General: Italian Campaign Introduction.

The introductory version linked above is the first release in the series and is currently available as a production version and a free Print & Play version.

Collins Epic Wargames provides rules support via website forums and e-mail and also publishes a Newsletter called Frontline General News with in-depth articles, examples, and previews of upcoming products.  All back issues of FG News are available online.

Name: LEGO Playground
Description:
From the box back:

Kids love playgrounds - an they love counting, too!  In this clever preschool counting game, players travel around the colorful paths in search of LEGO bricks.  Each LEGO brings players one step closer to reaching the tree house - winning the game!

Along the way, they may get to play hopscotch, which gives them an extra turn.  Look out for the sandbox - land in it, and you'll lose a turn!

Three levels of play make this a game for even the youngest players.

Name: Rennaissance Chess
Description:
Renaissance Chess (also known as Rennchess) is a large board (10 ranks x 12 files) chess variant with each player fielding an army of 34 pieces.  The 16 pieces found in an orthodox chess set are present along with some very powerful new pieces such as the Prince (combines the movement of a Queen and Knight), the Nobleman (combines the movement of the Rook and Knight), the Archbishop (combines the movement of the Bishop and Knight), the Cavalier (a side-stepping Rook type), the Duke (a side-stepping Bishop type), the Page (combines the movement of a King and Knight), and the Squire (moves or leaps 1 or 2 squares in a straight line).

The castling rules of orthodox chess are abandoned, but pawns are still able to utilize en-passant capture and retain their two-step first move capability.  Pawns which reach the opponent's back rank must promote to a previously captured piece.  Foxes which reach the opponent's back rank may optionally promote to a Guard.

According to Eric Greenwood, the game's author (in an article on ChessVariants.org), the correct spelling of the game should be "Renniassance" (the first "n" doubled and the "ai" reversed).

Name: Herocard Champion of New Olympia Ferrion Expansion Deck
Description:
From the back of the box:

FERRION EXPANSION DECK
Ferrion crushes evil with techno armor, advanced weapons, and maverick piloting skills.

Ferrion is a HeroCard Expansion Deck for HeroCard Champion of New Olympia, the ultimate fight for glory. Ferrion can compete in any HeroCard game or be combined with other decks to create a customized character.

CONTENTS
33 Character Cards
1 Figure

Expands

    HeroCard Champion of New Olympia

Name: Kentucky Derby
Description:
A game about horse racing in the American Kentucky Derby / Australian Melbourne Cup.  This is the re-themed,revamped and updated Whitman game that was first put out in 1938 as "Kentucky Derby". This is the revamped and updated Whitman game that was first put out in 1938. The 1961 version features much a fancier board with nicely rendered horses, betting slips and scorecards.

Re-implements:

    Kentucky Derby

Name: Chicago
Description:
This is a race between 2-4 gangsters and up to 23 policemen. The board depicts a town with 170 hex spaces. 60 of them are specially marked and are filled with turned down "houses".

1 player takes the role of the police and the others take the role of the gangsters. The gangsters can enter the houses and take the tiles laying there. Some of them are worth just money, but there are also tiles with several transportation possibilities like cars or planes, which allows faster movement than normal or robbing a bank.

While the game proceeds, the police player will get more and more policemen. He must try to eliminate the gangsters by surrounding them completely. The game ends when all gangsters have left the town.

A little strange the victory conditions: the gangster with the highest amount of prey is the winner. There is no given victory condition for the police player, but it's suggested to play as many games as there are players, so each player has been the police once!

Name: Der Weg nach Drakonia Essen '05 Promo Cards
Description: Four additional cards for "Der Weg nach Drakonia". First a give-away at Essen 2005, now (as long as supplies last) available by mail from Fanpro.

Name: The Art of War: Tactical Warfare in Miniature for Pre-gunpowder Armies
Description:
Short version of the game is: It plays fast. Usually a battle takes about an hour. It doesn't really matter how the figs are based. Its fairly bloody. Figs are pulled as they are killed. It has the tactics mechanisms built in, so you really only need to worry about what the army you're running is capable of. We strive for historical accuracy, and have a pretty high success rate for duplicating real fights.

* Basic rules, plus a Crusades mini-campaign appendix including 9 armies lists: 62 pages. The Basic Rules are comprehensive, and include siege warfare rules and rules for special weapons such as elephants, chariots and pavises (a large convex shield of European origin used to protect the entire body).
    * Standard 15mm to 40mm frontages used: no rebasing of figurines required. (Although singly-based miniatures work best, multiple-figurine bases work OK in most situations.)
    * Plus 84 additional pages of seven period appendices listing over 160 more armies:
    * Greek & Macedonian Armies
    * Ancient Armies of the Bronze Age
    * Ancient Armies of the Iron Age
    * Ancient Roman and Italian Armies
    * European Dark Ages Armies 500 to 1000 A. D.
    * European Medieval Armies 1000 to 1460 A. D.
    * Chinese, Huns, Mongols and Japanese Armies

Download version can be purchased at www.wargamedownloads.com

Name: Princess Ryan's Space Marines: Squad Combat in the 23rd Century
Description:
Princess Ryan's Space Marines is a simple game of individual and small unit combat in the not too distant future. Tested at many conventions by gamers of all ages, it is easy enough for grammar school and junior high students to play, yet is challenging enough for the veteran gamer. Although set in its own speculative history, the system is very flexible. It fits in well with almost any other science fiction setting or universe, including those you create yourself.

includes:
- 48 lead armor units @ 1/285 scale
- 2 dice
- instructions & scenarios(3) booklet
- Combat Results Table (CRT)

Re-implemented by:

    Princess Ryan's Star Marines

Name: HeroCard Champion of New Olympia: Talon Expansion Deck
Description:
From the back of the box:

TALON EXPANSION DECK
Talon hunts his prey using his uncanny instincts and his deadly arsenal.

Talon is a HeroCard Expansion Deck for HeroCard Champion of New Olympia, the ultimate fight for glory. Talon can compete in any HeroCard game or be combined with other decks to create a customized character.

CONTENTS
33 Character Cards
1 Figure

Expands

    HeroCard Champion of New Olympia

Name: Hawaiian Scene
Description:
"You are about to experience the Hawaiian Scene -- living and working in a Pacific paradise while purchasing and developing your favorite Island properties.  A weekend in Maui, snorkeling at Hanauma Bay, and the excitement of Waikiki -- all part of the Hawaiian Scene.  Before you play be prepared to deal with the "Big Five," make peace with labor leaders, influence the Mayor and hire a Kahuna to ensure your success.  Get ready to move fast, play hard, and take risks -- for you're in Hawaii and rolling for high stakes!"
Basically this is a travel variant of Monopoly, with some added mechanics in the form of collecting labor leaders and Kahunas to increase your capital and leverage.  The properties are all Hawaiian businesses circa 1978.

Name: Big Sunday Football
Description:
From the website:

Big Sunday Football plays closer to real football than any other game. Running, Passing, Kicking, Penalties, Sacks, Interceptions, Fumbles, 2-minute Warning, 2 point conversion, bad call by officials flag picked up. You name it, Big Sunday has it, except audibles. For ages 7-adult. Endorsed by NFL Coaches and Players. When you roll doubles look to the rule chart.
You may have broken a tackle or if you sacked the QB doubles means he fumbled the ball. You may have intercepted the pass and three doubles in a row means Touchdown return.

Name: Man o' War: Napoleonic Naval Warfare Rules
Description:
A very concise rule set for Napoleonic naval warfare using 1/3000 scale ship miniatures. The rules are self described as having "loopholes in them, but if you like your games fast, furious and bloody, these rules should work for you".
There is much definition missing from the rules, and they would appeal to gaming friends who do not mind compromising on complexity, and who are not prone too much to arguing over rules.
Damage is recorded on record cards.

Name: Sword and Pistol: Rules for Renaissance Skirmishes
Description:
Rules for Renaissance Skirmishes

The English Civil War, the Three Musketeers, Swords and the fall of the Armored Knight are all included within this skirmish game.

To be fought between 8-12 figures on a side, the detail is complete to replicate the period fighting style(s) and technology.

28 pages and a Quick Reference sheet that pulls out of the booklet.

Name: Quick Jump It's a Skunk!
Description: This is a fast reaction game where you try be the last one with all your marbles in your upper ramp zone.  A motorized skunk runs around a track and will bump your character if you do not push a button down fast enough to have your character jump out of his way.  If he bumps you, the marble will roll down to the lower zone; once all your marbles are at the bottom, you are out.  Last one with marbles in the top zone wins.

Name: Battle-Axe: Wargames Rules for Medieval Skirmishes
Description:
Wargame for Medieval Skirmishes

A painted knight on a hex base take on a man at arms while a couple of archers fling arrows at him. How he swings his sword is factored in the turn and the priority of thrusting before the cut or swings will dictates who will win.

28 pages with some hex pattern "board", charts for orders and abilities and a pull out Summary Sheet help the gameplay.

One small Erratum sheet:

Please note that on the summary sheet 2 for firing and melee, the Melee Procedure contains a typing error:
Line 4 should read "For each hit throw 3 D6 & add attacker's AA."

Name: Winx Club Magisch Bordspel
Description:
This is a game based on the TV show Winx Club and is meant for ages 6 and up.

The aim of the game is to be the first to finish the complete path of the board. This board contains 2 parts, one round for each of the 3 Colleges and an external round, common for all players.

Each player gets 5 cards from the stack with "Magic"- cards, 2 cards from the stack with Special Cards. The cards should be kept hidden from the other players.

Each player rolls the 6 sided die and moves his pawn accordingly on the board. After finishing the inner College round, the route goes further around the outer board. The first player to reach the circle numbered 66 is the winner of the game.

On several places on the board there are things happening which can influence the course of the game. Some duals have to be solved with the aid of "Special"-cards, or questions have to be answered from the stack with "Fairy, Witch or Specialist"-cards.

The "Magical"-cards  represent  the ingredients needed for the spells.

Name: Retinue: Medieval Skirmish Rules
Description:
Retinue

Per Wikipedia:
A retinue (Old French retenue, from retenir also meaning 'to employ', from Latin retenere, hold back, retain) is a body of persons "retained" in the service of a noble or royal personage, a suite (literal French meanings: what follows) of "retainers."

A Retinue is sometimes confused with an entourage, which is the far less stable body of people that followed whether or not they were -or claimed to be- retained or protected by the prominent person they served.

This game, albiet about knights fighting knights, recreates the true method of travel for a knight during the Middle Ages; Never alone!

This skirmish rule set of 42 pages and 2 pull out charts moves from a simple Retinue moving and meeting a group of bandits to Siege warfare. Suitable for a campaign game and weekend warriors, and provides some historical insight on the middle ages (A Knight's Tale" not withstanding)

Name: B.U.opoly
Description: This game is a variant of Monopoly, with cards and property names changed to items of interest for Boston University students, alumni and staff.  Although the basic gameplay is the same as Monopoly, the dollar values and card text has changed in B.U.opoly, resulting in different economics than the game upon which it is based.

Name: Flieger greifen an!
Description: An old German game, published in the 40s. An easy one with fighters, bombers, recons, Flak and balloons.The attacker has to fight for the railway station and the defender has to defend it.

Name: Wise Guys
Description:
Wise Guys is a collection of 10 spelling games that utilize the same board and letter tiles.  The letters are divided into three groups: Blue tiles (vowels-A,E,I,O), Green tiles (common consonants & "U"), and Pink tiles (less common consonants & wild "infinity" tiles).  Certain spaces on the board have a color & symbol that might affect scoring or word placement.

Some of the games are simple and suitable for young spellers, while other games are more complex.  The winning condition for most games is either (1) to score more points than opponents or (2) to use more letter tiles than opponents.  Players face their own letters in the upright position based on their seat at the table, and, in most games, your letters cannot contact opponents' words.  When scoring is based on points, the letter value is based on its color -- one point for blue, two for green and three for pink.

Name: Pippi och sjörövarna
Description:
"An exciting adventure game"

You're sailing the South Seas with Pippi and the pirates, on an exciting cruise on Pippi's ship Hoppetossa. While visiting a small island, Pippi's feet start to tingle strangely - it's time for a good old brawl and fight after a long sailing! Challenge the five pirates - Pollus, Hot Tin Pan, Oomalat, Dummerkopfen and cook O'Malley - into a dice duel on the gangplank. You'll also need gold coins from the island to bribe them. If you win the pirate you'll get to push him into the sea - but if you lose, it's YOU who'll end up in the drink, and need to swim back to the island for some more coins from Pippi's famous suitcase! Once you get to the ship itself, you need to face ALL the remaining pirates one after the other - unless you're lucky and they're all swimming already, in which case you win an instant victory and get to hoist the flag in Hoppetossa's mast!

Name: Regimental Chess
Description:
(From the Introduction in the rules.)
Regimental Chess is ...  a battle by a division of chess pieces on a (board) three times larger than traditional chess.

Each side has 14 infantrymen (pawns), 4 bishops, 4 knights, 4 rooks, 2 queens, and a king. Pieces may move individually or in battalions. A battalion is the group of each piece type, e.g. 4 bishops are a battalion. Battalion movement is all pieces making the same move (e.g., three diagonally northwest). It's like station keeping in naval fleet movement. Or battalions can move in a chain, each advancing forward to take the place of the other, like marching forward. All pieces have to spaced apart equally for chain movement.

It was a commercially available game. The map provided was a roll up chess board. The pieces were of good quality plastic in the traditional Staunton chess piece style.

Name: Pandemonium
Description:
A free to print game by Patrice Vernet with the same mechanics of Katmandou.

The game is set in medieval Europe, when most of it was suffering from Plague. Your mission is to eradicate the plague, by controlling  population movements and by using the expertise of special characters (Inquisitor, Physician, Wizard, etc.).

This game is a more spiced up version of Katmandou.

Name: Robinson
Description:
The center of the huge board shows a scene from Robinson Crusoe, on the outer part of the board are 4 images in 4 different colors. Each player plays with the 4 images of his color, that is he collects multi-colored tiles, which match the drawings on the images.

Tiles are won through the throw of 2-4 dice, depending on the number of "finished" images.

Winner is the player who completes the 4 images first.

Name: Schmetterling
Description:
Schmetterling (=butterfly) contains 44 flower tiles, 20 butterfly tiles and 4 tokens for each player. The flower tiles are diagonally separated into 2 halves showing two parts of a flower. Both halves have also a number on it (0-4). The butterfly tiles have numbers from 4 - 24.

Tiles are laid on the table like in dominoes: flower parts must have the same colors are adjacent flower parts. Every time, when a player lays the 4th flower part, a whole flower is completed and that player gets a butterfly card and puts a token on the flower to mark it as his flower.

When the first player has put all his 4 tokens on the table, the tile laying phase ends and the final calculation is done. The numbers on all 4 parts of completed flowers are summarized and if the player possessing it has a butterfly tile with that number, he scores these points. Winner is the player with the most points.

Name: Blockade
Description:
The game is played of a board which reminds of the petals of a flower. Each player has 1 moving token only, but there are also 70 neutral (blocking) tokens in the game. The idea of Blockade predates Amazons.

At the beginning, both player place their moving and one neutral token on the board. Each subsequent turn, a player must move his token to an adjacent empty space. Then, he places a neutral token on the board trying to surround his opponent. The players wins who manages that the token of his opponent cannot move anymore.

On the first move, a restriction applies for both players. Neither the moving nor the blocking token may be placed in a marked area in the center of the board. Together with the slightly irregular board, this is supposed to cancel out any first move advantage.

Name: Legrand
Description:
Each player has a set of 20 tiles of different shapes and sizes: 12 x 5-size, 5 x 4-size, 2 x 3-size and 1 x 2-size (88 squares in total). The game is played on a 14x14 board, but five 2x2 spaces are forbidden areas - giving 176 playable spaces.

Each tile has small triangles on all sides. If 2 pieces are laying attached to each other, the triangles form squares on the common sides. These squares are called "towers" and they are important to capture opposing pieces, since they represent the strength of attacking/defending tiles.

Winner of the game is the player who is the first who can lay down all his 20 tiles on the board.

Name: Time Bomb
Description: Wind up the time bomb and the players toss the loudly ticking device amongst themselves. The player caught holding the device when it stops ticking and pops is eliminated from play. The sole surviving player is the winner.

Name: Pavement Pals Activity Book & Chalk
Description:
This is nothing more than a book outlining 14 outdoor activities (including several games) that can be played with the included sidewalk chalk (in 6 colors, hence the suggested maximum number of players in this entry).

Some games are no-brainers (Hopscotch, Tic-Tac-Toe) others are a bit unusual (drawing a race track and alternately flicking chalk to draw lines of advancement around the track).

Essentially, it's a structured set of sidewalk chalk.

Name: The Horseless Carriage Race
Description:
This very early game from McLoughlin Brothers of New York was produced just as automobiles came on to the scene as viable transportation. The map showed the U.S., southern Canada, and northern Mexico with major cities such as New York, New Orleans, Mexico City, Los Angeles and Quebec depicted.

In this game, players race across the country. The cars are moved by spinning a cardboard rondel.

The game was a simple spin and move game which featured spots on the board where one might lose a turn because of breakdowns or repairs.

Name: Tanbark Trail
Description:
Tanbark Trail attempts to simulate the exciting world of Holstein show ring competition. The object of the game is to win ribbons and trophies which at the end of the game are converted to points. The player with the most points wins.

At the start of the game, a set number of cattle are auctioned off to the players. During the game, players may purchase more cattle from the sales barn, sell animals back to the sales barn, or trade or purchase from each other.

There are also random event cards drawn during the game that operate much like "Chance" or "Community Chest" cards in Monopoly.

Players move around a board depicting a fairgrounds, at the center of which is the show ring. Any time a player moves his token into the show ring, a competition begins. At this point players must pay an entry fee for each animal they wish to enter in each show class. First, second, and third-place winners are determined by combining die rolls with stats on that animal's card.

The first three rounds of show competition are considered to be State competitions, and the fourth a National competition. After the fourth round, all award ribbons are converted to points, and the winner is determined.

Name: Starsiege: Rebellion
Description:
'Starsiege: Rebellion' is a miniatures game set in Sierra/Dynamix's "Starsiege" universe.  Forces present include the Imperials (humans from Earth), Rebels (human colonials on Mars who stumble into advanced alien technology to allow them to rebel), and Cybrids (humanity's long-time enemy...machines who attempted to destroy their creators several times in the past, and each time being beaten back).  At the point of the game, the Cybrids had established a final base around Pluto from which they began a new invasion after the humans started fighting amongst themselves.

There are not many 'scenarios', but the production values are pretty decent - and the game box includes a bucket of miniatures.

The gameplay features unit activation as a combination of laying chits by units and rolling a die, and the combat has some very elegant twists that make it resolve FAST - only 2 dice (one determined by range, the other determined by skill of the firing unit) for are needed to resolve all damage from an attack.  As a result, the game is not very "nitty gritty", like Battletech, but takes a higher-level view of action.  Scenarios played with a dozen units would be over in half an hour, easily, and scenarios with many dozens of units would be playable in an afternoon.

Boxed set includes:

     96-page rulebook 
     29 vehicle data cards
     Master Equipment/Master Weapons Reference Card
     Meeting Engagement Scenario Setup Card
     FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions) Sheet
     80 full-color die-cut counters
     5 full-color die-cut templates
     5 dice (4-, 6-, 8-, 10-, and 12-sided) 
     18 unpainted miniatures


Imperial
- 4 Talon Scout Hercs 
- 4 Obsidian Hover Tanks 
- 1 Minotaur Herc 
Cybrid 
- 4 Seeker Scout Hercs 
- 4 Manta Hover Tanks 
- 1 Shepherd Herc 
- 4 hills (thermal plastic, flocked, from 2" to 7" across)

Name: Buzzword
Description:
Buzzword -- The Fastest Word Game Ever!

Players roll out their letter dice, then take turns making words from the upturned letters.  The first player places the first word on a "start square" on the 13x13 board.  All subsequent words must use a letter from a word already on the board, or must extend or alter a word already on the board.

Players have one minute to complete each move.  If time runs out before all the player's letters are in place, the turn is lost.

Play continues until neither player can place any more dice, or until one player has used all of their dice.  That is the end of one round -- three rounds constitute a game.

Before each round, players take turns selecting a "buzzword," which is any four-letter word.  If during play, a player is able to make the buzzword, they get a 25-point bonus.

Name: Real-Action Baseball
Description:
From the box cover: The game that's just like real baseball -- you actually make every play!  Play fielders where you want!  Send men after moving ball!  Players field ball, run with it, throw to basemen who cover bags!  You move batter, runners!  Baseball know-how, strategy, luck!  Fast-moving -- takes about 1/2 hour!  Based on 2000 big league games!  Scores just like in the majors!  Sturdy board, 18 men, ball!

Basically, a spinner (1 to 6) is spun three times.  The results of these spins determine the play -- a first spin "1" is a walk or a strikeout.  Once the ball is in play and the location has been determined, the defensive player moves the fielders to the ball before arrows push the ball past.  The offensive player moves the batter until the play is resolved.

Name: Hank Aaron Baseball Game
Description: Players take turns batting and pitching on the game's plastic stadium.  The pitchers sends a marble-sized wooden ball down a chute, by rolling, snapping, or spinning the ball, and the batter attempts to hit the ball by spinning a dial that swings the bat.  If hit, the ball is sent flying across and out of the stadium.  If the pitcher catches the ball, it's an out; if not, the batter gets a single, double, triple, or home run, depending on where the ball left the stadium.

Name: Templaria
Description: Similar to a classic game (Scopa) and located in the history, with cards of Templars and Santo Graal.

Name: Adesso ci penso
Description:
Aim of the game is to build up a complete and grammatically correct sentence. Each player can use just a word on each one of the seven cards he/she holds knowing that:
- on the cards a verb is in infinitive tense and it can be declined in every tense;
- adjectives, nouns, articles can be male of female, singular or plural;
- commas and full stops can be freely added;
- no other word can be used but only the ones on the cards, and just one word per card.

Name: Media Mogul
Description:
Build your media empire!

The Media Mogul owns all of the assets in one of the 6 Markets.

Invest in real media assets by blind bidding against other players. You'll need a range of TV channels, radio and magazines, to corner one of the 6 Markets themed by content eg. fashion, arts, mens', music

It's a bit like poker - with lots of emotion raising eye contact etc and the thrill of gambling. And it is cool buying up MTV, Channel 4 and Hello! no matter how much of an anti-media guru you are...

Name: The Shepherd's Game
Description: The Shepherd's game, or Schäferspiel, is an early roll and move game, unique in that it employs the rolling of two dice. One normal d6, and the other with color designation. The game offers multiple movement options as the color dice designates which pawns are able to move.  Money is awarded when farmers land on designated spots while either sheep or dogs are also on specific spaces.  Winner is the shepherd with the most money when all sheep are finally herded back into their pasture.

Name: Geographisches Lotto
Description: Geographisches  Lotto is a 19th century parlor game with its base design similar to that of Bingo.  The main difference here is that each player either has a map of the eastern or western hemisphere and match numbers to locations on the map instead of the usual bingo grid.

Name: Sea Rover
Description:
Three Nations fight in a Caribbean-like Sea against each other or vs. the evil Pirate Lord . You can find ghost ships, 
castaways, treasures. Build ships, trade with cities or loot them. All what a Pirate movie needs ... Aye

Name: Mabinogion
Description: In days long ago, great Celtic heroes and heroines carved out kingdoms for themselves in the land we now call Wales. Legend tells of their encounters with conceited dragons, evil witches, ferocious giants, terrifying wights, and not forgetting the fickle but powerful Fair Folk. Mabinogion brings Celtic legend to life by allowing you to role play, and share the fate of, those characters. You will fulfil hazardous quests in your search for fame and fortune, whilst trying to prevent your rivals from doing the same. Love, war, luck, and clever diplomacy all play a part as the game unfolds. Mabinogion is a Welsh word meaning Ê»stories of heroesÊ¼, and many heroic adventures await you in the game. So take a journey back to the Dark Ages and live amongst the legend, myth, and romance of ancient Wales!

Name: Grimoire des Illusions
Description:
To represent the people of the Men or the people of the imps and to mark more points than its adversary. To obtain these points one looks at the end of each part what one recovered in his folds (folds makes during the part).

If the Black book of the Illusions is recovered, 12 points are marked. If one recovers more books than his adversary, one marks 9 points to have constituted the largest library. Are also marked points if the couple of his people is recovered, to have the largest population, if places are invested!

To make folds (even raised that in Scopa or Escoba), it is enough to pose a chart of its play on one or two charts of the same value on the table of play. For example one 8 of my play can take a chart 8 on the table of play some is the color. Or, one 8 of my play can take a chart of 6 and one of 2 on the table (6+2=8).

When all the charts in hand were played, each camp counts the points contained in the folds carried out, and then one sets out again for another game...

Name: Haus-Nummer
Description: Players lay out 9 cards with numbers from 1-9. Each turn, a player throws 2 dice and turns over 2 cards depicting the numbers on the dice, or 1 card showing the sum of the 2 dice. The game is over after the fifth dice throw! The cards that could not be turned over are assembled to one number and the player with the lowest number is the winner.

Name: Die diebischen Elstern
Description:
In "Die diebischen Elstern" (=the thievish magpies) 2-4 players attempt to be the first player who can collect 6 different objects.

The board size is 5x5 spaces. The space in the middle is neutral and the 24 other spaces show all 6 objects in the 4 colors of the players. Movement can be done to any adjacent space. If a player lands on an space of his color, he can take that object and put it on his scoreboard. If he lands on an space with another color, he can steal that object, if he does not have this object yet and if the affected player has it on his scoreboard.

The game is very easy to learn, but not as easy to play as you would expect. It's difficult to concentrate on your own moves as well as on the possible moves of your opponents. And the fact that each object   shows up 4 times on the board, does not help reduce the confusion.

Name: Halo
Description:
The board shows a star surrounded by 2 x 3 orbits. Each player has 6 meteors (tokens). They start outside of the board and are moved from orbit to orbit to the star in the center with the help of a die.

If the die roll is high enough, the meteor is gravitated by the star in the center, but if the roll is too low, it will drive off the center. But the chances for being gravitated can be increased by building stacks of meteors (up to 4 meteors of any player's meteors can be stacked).

Winner of the game is the player, whose meteors reach the center first.

Name: 1838: Rheinland
Description:
1838 Rheinland is an 18xx game designed and self-published by Wolfram Janich.

It is intended to be a short game, obviously located in the area of one of the most industrial area of Germany, the Rhine valley from Bonn to the RuhrGebiet (Essen).


     mainly a variant of 1835 (trains X+x, last share is 20%, nationalization, corporations floated with 50%) with 1830: Railways & Robber Barons features (stock market, privates auction)
     6 corporations
     the Rhine can only be crossed in a few places in main cities (this represents the fact that the Prussian army did not allow, for defense reasons, the building of bridges over the Rhine)
     special bonuses: coal mines and steel mills
     small map (around 60 hexes)


A revised version has been published as 18Rhl: Rhineland.

Name: Scriptorium
Description:
(Description from the publisher:)
You make up words using your letters to a selected theme.
You put them down, or move around those already on the table.
You defend them against other players... you can reject them!
The first player who has no more cards wins the game and... "Rien ne va plus!"

Name: Häst-Hopp
Description:
Häst-Hopp is a children's game for ages 5 and up for 2-3 players. The title translates into Horse Jump.

You pick your favorite horse and compete in horse jumping. Draw tiles and build your courses side-by-side. Jump the bars with the help of the color-coded die. The fastest horse wins.

Game-play is entirely driven by chance in the shape of a stack of tiles and a die. The only skill involved is whether to use some rare free-jump tiles on an easy or a difficult obstacle.

Name: SITS Ship Book 2: The Silesian Confederacy
Description:
Ship Book 2, the first supplement for Saganami Island Tactical Simulator, set in the Honor Harrington universe.

Silesia, a wretched mishmash of corrupt governments, star-navies for hire, piracy and trade opportunities. Long fallen from its heights as an enlightened confederation of planetary governments, Silesia is the proving ground that the Andermani Empire and the Star Kingdom of Manticore send their newly minted officers and crews to patrol.

Ship Book 2 explores the history of Silesia, the customs and uniforms of the Imperial Andermani Navy and Confederacy Navy, while providing pirate hunting scenarios, a sampling of Silesian, Andermani, Pirate and civilian ships.

Expands:

    Saganami Island Tactical Simulator

Name: Monopoly: M&M's
Description:
Another Monopoly edition, this time with an m&m's design.

6 pewter tokens picturing different m&m's dispensers.
The properties are also m&m's related.

Name: Chaos! Rules!
Description:
From the website:

The object of the game is to spell the word CHAOS! (in any order) on the table in front of you.

The deck consists of Letter Cards and Action Cards. There should be 32 Letter Cards(C, H, A, O, S, and "!" [exclamation point]) that say "CHAOS! RULES!" in lavender on the backs. The 40 Action Cards say "CHAOS! RULES!" in yellow on the backs. These cards feature specific actions that are to be followed immediately after the card is played.

Name: Empire Deck
Description: The Empire Deck contains two complete new suits of cards, crowns and anchors (Haats & Hooks), in addition to the standard playing cards, for a total of 78 cards.  The deck includes rules for rummy and hearts variants which can be played using the extra suits.

Name: Word Rally!
Description:
Word Rally: The Fast-Paced Word Search Game!  This travel game, published in 1999, is composed of a large plastic d6 that contains 9 six-sided lettered die.  Players roll the large die, count words a la Boggle*, and score them by the multiplier on the outer cube.

*All the words you find on your turn score for you.  For the other players, only the words they find that you didn't score for them.  There is no adjacency, like in Boggle.  All shown letters are available in any order.  So not quite "a la Boggle".

Name: Frundsberg
Description:
First published in the same box as Xerxes. The "Frundsberg" - board was printed on the back of the double-sided board.

Differences to Xerxes:
- units are deployed secretly
- new terrain (rivers) can only be walked through slowly
- enemies camp enlarged to 2 spaces

Name: Kampf der Gartenzwerge
Description:
This game was invented 1977 as "Organisms" by Sid Sackson. It was published in the Swiss newspaper "Tagesanzeiger" on October, 13th. 1982 as "Kampf der Gartenzwerge" and later in Spielbox 3/87 as "Krawall im Paradies".

The game is played on a 9x11 board. Both players have 21 tokens divided among 3 groups (6,7 and 8 pieces per group). Each group has 1 leader, 2 special pieces and 3-5 normal pieces.

Object of the game is to capture 2 of the opposing leaders first.

Movements can be done space by space or by jumping as far as wanted, but the 3 groups should always stay together. Isolated groups member will be flipped over and are blocked until the end of the game. This can be a hard problem, because the normal pieces can only capture opposing people by isolating themselves, while the 9 "better" pieces don't have that restriction.

Name: Hentacle: Three's an Orgy
Description:
Three's An Orgy is the second supplement for the gooey and nonsensical game, Hentacle.

This expansion expands the basic game with two new girls and their associated cards but doesn't make any drastic changes or major introductions to the game.

This set was completed with the aid of our new artist, Darkzel, whose style should compliment the previous cards well, while creating a fresh new image for the game.

Enjoy your perversity!

Name: Ruhmreiche Ritter
Description: Players change the maze and then memorize the path their knight must take.  Put on the blindfold, roll the die, then tell another player which direction to move your knight.  The first player to rescue their princess wins.

Name: Milk and Cheese's Stupid Little Boardgame!
Description:
A boardgame built on the manic humor of Evan Dorkin's Milk and Cheese, Dairy Products Gone Bad!
A simple roll and move game that was free in an issue of Wizard in 1995. Funny if you are a fan of the characters.

Name: The Brass Monkey Game
Description:
"It's World War II and you're an Allied spy, one of the most cunning spies in the business. Your assignment is the most dangerous you have ever undertaken. You must enter the exotic and perilous island of Macao, center of a teeming network of international spies just off the coast of China."

"Once on Macao, you secretly make your way to the legendary Brass Monkey Club, site of the local espionage network and the place where you will make contact with the Master Spy himself, H.E. Rasske. But before you reach the sin-infected Brass Monkey Club, your life and your country's security are endangered many times."

-- rulebook excerpt

To win the game you need to move around the board, collect at least three Brass Monkey cards, and be the first to land on the Brass Monkey Club at the end of the track by an exact roll of the dice. Fail to make the exact roll and you might find yourself starting from the beginning of the trail again! Minor complications are introduced by the Risk cards, while Subterfuge cards aid you in your clandestine mission.

-- player summary

Name: Permutations
Description:
Described in Parlett's The Oxford History of Board Games.

The game has 144 squares in three colors (12 x 12 grid) and each player has twelve pieces, four of each color, the players are differentiated by shape. Pieces move in any orthogonal or diagonal direction one space, or over an unbroken line of pieces of any shape or color, provided it lands on its own color.  The object of the game is to get all of the pieces into the line on the opposing side of the field, a la Jumpin or Chinese Checkers.

Name: Kodo
Description:
From Ee J. Frankel, Play It Again: Asian Games and Pastimes

"The incense game or incense ceremony (kôdô) probably had its origin in the Heian Period when such aesthetic skills as the identification of fragrances became part of the training of aristocrats.  Gradually, literary themes became associated with certain fragrances.  Sometime in the following Muromachi period (1185-13??), the game evolved into a complicated pastime that required a larger variety of scents than previously used, and accommodated up to ten guests as participants.
  By the early Edo period, the game reached new heights of popularity, probably due to the formalization of the tea ceremony, that also included the burning of incense.  During the eighteenth century, possibly because of a shortage of imported scented woods (kôboku), the incense ceremony survived only among the very rich and wealthy merchants who also introduced a modified version of the game and its accoutrement's.  What follows is a description of the typical components of the Incense Game of the very early part of the Edo period (1615-1867).
  The game is customarily played with four fragrances (in the form of pieces of scented wood), three of which are supplied by the host and one by a guest.  The three house scents are each divided into four portions that are placed in individual packets, making a total of twelve packets of house fragrances.  The guest fragrance is put into one packet, making a grand total of thirteen.
  In the preliminary round, the three house fragrances are introduced and identified for the players (the guest fragrance remaining a mystery).  Then the game begins and is played out in ten rounds, during which each of the players attempts to distinguish the four possible scents they are currently being given to identify.
  In the simplest form of the game, the preliminary round begins with the guests or players (usually highly literate people, sensitive to poetry) seated close enough together for the burning incense to be passed among them easily.  The host, who has prepared small pieces of burning charcoal in a larger burner, or kôro, lifts a piece of the red-hot charcoal with the proper tool, and buries it within the lacquered, ash-filled kikikôro (a special metal-lined container for this purpose), leaving over it only a thin covering layer of ash.  The ash is then smoothed and rounded into a cone with a spatula-like tool.
  When the guests appear comfortable, the host opens one packet of the three house fragrances, gives it an identifying name such as "Fragrance One" and then places the perfumed wood on a mica square that is in turn placed on the heated ash.  The burner is then passed around for the guests to acquaint themselves with the fragrance.  Fragrance Two and Fragrance Three are then introduced and identified in the same manner.  After all three pieces of scented wood have been gently sniffed, each is placed on one of a set of plum-blossom-shaped rests provided for this purpose.  Then the game proper begins.
  At this point ten packets of fragrance remain -- nine of house fragrances and one unknown -- and the players will now have to identify them without being told which is which.
  Each player will have been provided with a set of counters or ballots, all of which have that player's identifying token (some tree or flower) on one side, and a possible choice (Fragrance One, Fragrance Two, Fragrance Three, or Unknown Fragrance) on the other.  As each new packet is opened and its contents placed in the burner and then passed around, each player chooses a counter that matches his or her guess about its identity and drops it into a receptacle provided for that purpose.  The burner is passed around again, the fragrances inhaled, and their identities guessed ten times.  Sometimes these actions may be accompanied by the scent or alluding to the floral picture on the player's ballot.  As the closed room quickly fills with lingering odors from previous rounds, the game becomes increasingly more difficult.
  After each round the ballots are examined, and the players' guesses are written by brush on a record board. (Sometimes the ballots are put in an envelope until the game is completed and the guesses registered on the board at that time.) The winner is often awarded the record board.  Depending on the time available and the number of guests, a recess may be called and food served in another area."

Name: Sea Rats!
Description:
As the rules put it "The object o' Sea Rats! is to be the last pirate afloat".

Each player starts with one ship, six cannonballs, and six crates of supplies used to repair damage. The ships are positioned on a sea map board that can be rolled up for storage. Each ship starts at a different port. Cargo can be gained or lost by moving to ports, fighting other ships, and bribing, extorting, or trading with other pirates.

Dice rolls determine which port you can stock up at next, how much cargo you load, how far you move, and whether your cannonballs hit the ship you aim at. You may also attempt to take "The Treasure" which may be used as a bribe that can't be refused, to buy an extra die for movement, or to buy an extra cargo die with the ability to overload your ship. Possession, not expenditure, of the treasure allows docking at any port.

A ship hit with more cannonballs than it has crates sinks to Davy Jones' Locker, and the losing captain is out of the game. The victorious captain may expend his own crates to keep the ship from sinking and control an additional ship himself, or allow the previous captain to stay on in a subservient role and continue to play the ship if "he/she swears an oath o' allegiance". This can be used in many cases to keep all players involved in the game to the end.

From the Publisher:

AVAST YE!
 Welcome te Sea Rats!™, the most excitin' pirate board game this side o' the Ivory Coast. Where old salts and landlubbers alike sail ships on the high seas, battle with their enemies, stock up at ports o' call, an', best of all, steal The Treasure—Arrrghhh!

Send yer buddies down te Davy Jones' Locker. Capture "the prize" an' build up a fleet o' ships! Bribe yer enemies te escape hostile fire—whatever it takes te be the last pirate afloat an' win the game! It's easy te learn an' totally wicked fun to play!

Name: Not Tonight Josephine
Description:
Not Tonight Josephine is a historical trivia game. The game includes glass bead gaming pieces, a colorful board and question cards, many of which are also in color. There are two boxes for the cards, and cardboard coins, as well as dice.

There are 30 different question categories on the board, which uses a circular track with a hub layout. The question categories some are more traditional like "Ancient History", "Royalty" and "American Civil War", others are of a quirky nature such as "Famous Exits", "Cockney English" and "Submarines". Players draw a card which will have a choice between two categories from which to answer, all questions are multiple choice with three possible answers. If the player gets a question right they can roll again, if the question is the same category as the space the player is on they also receive a coin. The four special Double Trouble space on the board give the player a coin if they can answer both questions on the card. The player with five coins who then returns to the center of the board wins the game.

Name: Port-of-Call
Description: Players build and operate merchant fleets in Pacific rim trade. Buy, sell and lease freighters and tankers, purchase and bid on cargo contracts for delivery between ports, smuggle, buy and sell maritime insurance. Ships move by speed rating of 40, 60, or 70 knots based on ship type. Ending based on profit when all cargo is delivered, only one player has remaining ships, or upon agreed time limit.

Name: Minigolf
Description: Minigolf: the Roll-a-Coin game is a game for any number of people to play.  The wooden board is reconstructed with a different obstacle on each turn, and play consists of aiming and rolling a large coin towards a hole on the opposing end.  Score is kept like golf, with each roll counting against the player as one stroke.

Name: Communicate
Description:
From the publisher:
"Listen, understand, do and have fun at the same time. A game conducive to language development and communication and also good for shape comprehension and for training fine motor skills."

Essentially a two-player game, this can be played with more players by forming two-teams.

The two players (or teams) sit opposite each other and each player is given an identical kit with 26 wooden elements (cubes, prisms, bridges, etc).  The lid of the game box is setup as a vertical screen between the two players so that their wooden pieces and building projects in front of them is not visible to the other.

One player is chosen to be the master builder and the other is the apprentice. The master builder begins building a structure with his/her pieces (not visible to the other because of the screen) and verbally describes it as precisely as possible, as the building progresses. The 'apprentice' tries to follow the description givenby the master builder and attempts to build a replica of the structure with the pieces on his/her side of the screen.

Its exciting to compare the buildings when the screen is finally removed.

A further version (for players with practice) is "sign language", whereby the players may only use their hands to communicate.

Name: Say When!!
Description:
Based on the long-running (1961-65) game show, players take turns choosing prizes. Among these are grocery items, "blank checks"which allow the players to accumulate them in quantity. The individual value of the item is revealed, and the total value is added to the player's score. The player whose score is closer to $10,000 without going over wins.

Say When!! is usually remembered for a blooper involving a live commercial for Peter Pan peanut butter.

Name: Pass
Description:
The board looks very similar to a Malefiz-board and it also has barricade-fields.

But in Pass, players start in 2-4 corners of the board and must move to the opposite corner, so that the playing pieces move all in different directions. And the barricades are active only when the first token has landed on it. Passing these barricades in handled differently to Malefiz also.

Anyway, Pass looks more like a Malefiz variant than an absolutely new game.

Name: Rally
Description:
This is a car racing game with a variable track built out of 24 course tiles. The tiles have different designs and some of them have some special spaces printed on them.

The race starts just with the start tile on the table. Each turn, a player has the option to either add a tile to the course or throw a die to move his car. If a die roll cannot be used totally, the car does not move at all.

When the last tile has been put on the table, the cars must continue the race back to the start tile. The first arriving there, is the winner.

Name: Madman The Game!
Description:
A boardgame built on the manic humor of Mike Allred's Madman!
A simple roll and move game that was free in an issue of Wizard in 1995. Contents are a board and counters. Player must supply dice.

Name: Tier Combino
Description:
Tier-Combino is a memory variant with groups of 3 cards instead of 2 cards, but a player can reveal only 2 cards per turn as in normal memory.

The hexagon shaped cards show 15 such groups of 3 cards.

Name: Castello
Description: It's a game with a castle & knights theme. Who conquers the fortress Castello? The players have to move their knights to Castello in a tactical Way: Capturing their opponents pieces while not being captured themselves.

Name: Oase
Description:
Oase is played with 65 terrain tiles showing straight or curved roads, crossings and bridges; all with 1-4 movement points.

The 4 starting tiles are laid out on the table, and every turn, a player must proceed 1 movement point or draw a new tile and put it on the table.

Object of the game is to reach the starting tile, that laid in the opposite corner as the one, where the player left. The player who achieves that first, is the winner.

Name: Gedrängel
Description:
Gedrängel (=scramble) is a funny Malefiz variant, where all players can move with all playing pieces!

Opposite to Malefiz is the winning option: you must bring your 4 playing pieces AND 3 tokens of different colors to their target spaces to be the winner.

Name: Hi-Spy
Description:
Hi-Spy is a card game, where a player must get rid of his cards first to become the winner.

There are 112 cards: 
- 78 number cards (numbers 1-6, 13 from each)
-  7 UN cards
-  7 War cards
- 10 Peace cards
- 10 Spy cards

Players play cards face down under certain rules. The following player has the option to believe that these rules were observed, or he can ask for a check. Depending on what card is revealed, one of the two involved players is punished and the other is rewarded.

Name: Dhaemon
Description:
Played in Mauritania and Western Sahara, Dhaemon is a game similar to checkers and/or Seega. It is played on a 9x9 grid, usually made out of piled sand, and the opposing game pieces are frequently represented by short sticks on one side and dessicated camel droppings on the other. It has been featured in the travel book "Sahara" by Michael Palin, and the BBC TV series of the same name [2002].

It is possible that this is the game referred to as Srand or Dhamet by Lhôte.
Families: Traditional Games: Alquerque / Fanorona (Indian War Games)

Name: Bienenkönigin
Description:
Bienenkönigin (=Queen Bee)includes 2 games that are played on the same board of 11x10 hexes.

Game-1, for 2 players: 
Object of the game is the capture of the opposing queen bee.

Game-2, for up to 4 players:
Object of the game is to bring all playing pieces on the opposing side of the board. Captures are not allowed here.
